channel.title: Caffeine and Lasers - Book Reviews
channel.description: Book reviews and reading thoughts from Caffeine and Lasers

item.title: Negotiation by Max H. Bazerman
item.description:
Rating:

Type: Non-Fiction

item.title: The Avoidable War by Kevin Rudd
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

item.title: Being Human by Lewis Dartnell
item.description:
Rating: üüß

Type: Non-Fiction

The book promises a lot, the concept is an investigation to how biology has shaped human society and history. For a while it manages to hold up to that promise, the first few chapters are genuinely really interesting. By the midpoint of the book it starts to drag unfortunately, while the first few chapters investigate where cooperation and altruism comes from, the middle starts to talk about how disease affected colonialism, and how cognitive biases lead to poor decisions in leaders. Important? Yes. Groundbreaking? Not exactly.

item.title: Exile Economics by Ben Chu
item.description:
Rating: üüß

Type: Non-Fiction

I probably need to stop reading books with theses which I already agree with from the beginning. Turns out that economic protectionism and isolationism is bad for your economy. Who knew?

item.title: Careless People by Sarah Wynn-Williams
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

I knew Facebook did shady shit beforehand but the degree to which and the amount they knew that they were doing still managed to shock me. the metaphor the title implies, a reference to the Great Gatsby is extremely apt. The belligerence with which the Facebook leadership acted kind of blew me away. On the other hand, it is important to remember that this is and ex employee with an extra grind and she is bringing out all the dirty laundry. Personally, I tend to take a structural analysis point of view when talking about the problems with companies like Facebook. That Cory doctorow point about how the current cup of execs are not uniquely stupid or evil. They are just enabled by stupid laws. The book doesn't explore any of this, as far as Williams is concerned, the leadership at Facebook is uniquely evil and uncaring. I remember when I had to study Great Gatsby in high school, we had to discuss the degree to which our narrator was a reliable narrator. Because he was enjoying all the same spoils as the people he was criticizing. I wonder about Williams. If she wasn't sexually harassed and bullied out of her job, I wonder how critical she would be of Facebook. Would she have still been a whistleblower if she wasn't treated so horribly by the people in charge? I don't know, maybe.

item.title: More Everything Forever by Adam Becker
item.description:
Rating: üüß

Type: Non-Fiction

This ends up feeling like one of those documentaries about flat Earth consspiracy theorests, except the nutjobs in question are Peter Theil, Sam Altman and Venture Captialists. I found it frustrating at some points because of the ammount of time it spends debunking obviously stupid ideas. It definately brought up some insights into ideology of some of these people, but the book felt a little bit too long IMHO. The ideology it describes is so incoherent that I find myself wondering how useful understanding it really is. If the actions of longtermist effective altruists are indistinguishable from a selfish asshole, then I wonder why not just apply Occam's Razor and assume they are just selfish assholes?

item.title: How They Get You by Chris Kohler
item.description:
Rating: üü©*

Type: Non-Fiction

*If you willingly read the finance stories in the news or know a bit about personal finance, you can probably skip this book. But I would highly recommend buying for any teenagers or twenty-somethings in your life. (I know I would have liked to have read it earlier in my life.) It ends up being closer to a personal finance book than an economica book. Its insights arnt really anything I hadn't heard before, BUT it is well written, Kohler is a funny guy, and it's lessons are absolutely important (I just happened to know most of them beforehand) side note: this book also is extremely Australian and for Australian audiences. (a rare thing I'm this world). by that, I don't mean he is talking about riding your kangaroo to school, but instead he discusses reasonable rates for you superfund and how pokies impacts Aussies specifically

item.title: Challenger by Adam Higginbotham
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

It is embarrassing for me to admit that I work in the "Space Industry" but I barely know anything about space history, so I picked up this one.It was one of the most compelling non-fiction books I have ever read. It felt like reading a thriller. I swear I could hear the intense music kick in once I got to the chapter about the SRB O-rings. If you know you know. At a bit over 500 pages it is a bit of a commitment, but the breadth and depth of his reasearch was fantastic.

item.title: Life As No One Knows It by Sara Imari Walker
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Non-Fiction

This was a great read as a physicist. The book was written with quite a high level of assumed knowledge, so if thermodynamics sounds like a scary word, I might suggest reading something more accessible. For me though, the premise was very interesting and prompted me to go and read a number of the papers cited in the book. From what I can tell, the central concept of "Assembly Theory" is somewhat controversial in Astrobiology circles, so I am not sure I am fully on board with the idea, but it is very interesting to engage with and think about. The book has me thinking a lot about the distinction between systems with selection, random systems and designed systems. I may have to write another blogpost about these ideas. Maybe one about Assembly Theory as well.

item.title: Algospeak by Adam Aleksic
item.description:
Rating: üüß

Type: Non-Fiction

I was maybe a little bit more educated than the target audience for the book, because I found a lot of the points made a little bit obvious, and I was waiting for new information. The book is well written however, and has a very nice flow to it. I listened to it as an audiobook, so even got to listen to Aleksik perform the accents he was describing. Aleksik seems to be more optimistic about our algorithm future than I am, and I am not sure he convinced me. (I may just be cranky and cynical however). The one point I can confidently state that I disagree with: I think Aleksik overstates the effect of accents, because I think he over-estimates the proportion of posters-to-consumers on social media. I cannot see how a micro-cultural accent can occur when the line of communication is mostly mono-directional.

item.title: Snake Island by Ben Hobson
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Fiction

The review they stick in the front describes it as "Part western, part Greek tragedy" and I think that is a really good description. The story is very Australian, but not in a cheap way, and all the characters are fascinating. I don't read a lot of fiction and even less "literaqture" but this was really enjoyable

item.title: I Spy: My life in MI5 by Tom Marcus
item.description:
Rating: üüß

Type: Non-Fiction

Fair warning, this is straight up propaganda (it even had to pass MI5 clearance to publish) and is written like Tom Clancy. Nonetheless, it was really enjoyable to read. The narrative of it is mostly in the form of radio chatter which is a form I personally find gripping. Also kind of terrrifying to think how many terror plots get stopped, but it restored some level of my faith in instituitions to see the principaled stance that Tom and his team operated within.

item.title: Everything Is Tuberculosis by John Green
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

I never read John Green's YA fiction, since I was not a "YA" when I first came across it, BUT, I absolutely adored Crash Course History, and the way John thinks on Vlog Brothers. With this in mind, "Everything is Tuberculosis" is everything I hoped for. He places the diseases in the context of human history and present day human culture. He ends the book arguing that Tuberculosis used to be caused by bacterial infection, now it is caused by injustice, and it is our job to fix it.

item.title: No Power Greater: A History of Union Action in Australia by Liam Byrne
item.description:
Rating: üüß

Type: Non-Fiction

A bit of a slog to get through to be completely honest, but also incredibly important. The book tells the story of Australia through the lens of union action. Turns out almost all the institutions I like were thanks to unions. If you have ever said the words "Bob Hawke and Keating were Neoliberals" you should read this book to understand how that period of history really worked

item.title: the happiness of dogs: why the unexamined life is the most worth living by Mark Rowlands
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

this was a very accessible book on philosophy, i have previsoly struggled with a lot of "traditional" philosphy, e.g. netzsche and camus which who i've attempted to read several times and keep bouncing off. admittedly, when i picked it up i was expecting a self-help book, turns out it was a philosophy of mind book. very worthwile anyway.

item.title: Blindsight by Peter Watts
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Fiction

Blindsight falls into the club with the Matrix and the Three Body Problem, of being a piece of Sci-Fi who is primarily a piece of philosophy. It is a ***crunchy*** bit of sci-fi which explores transhumanism more thoroughly than any other piece I can think of. I have more thoughts which I will save for an extended blogpost I think.

item.title: Conflict: the evolution of warfare from 1945 to Gaza by General David Petraeus and Andrew Roberts
item.description:
Rating: üüß

Type: Non-Fiction

This is a complicated one to recommend. It was a bit of a slog to read, and parts of it were quite confronting. Without going too much into my own political ideology, I don't think it would be that surprising to most that I do not agree 100% with the political opinions espoused by a general of the U.S military. That said, I do think it is worth a read. Not because I agree with all the opinions of the author, but because I think it is very important for many to understand how a general of the U.S. military thinks.

item.title: The Village Teacher by Liu Cixin
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Fiction

Cixin does not miss. This short graphic novel which I read in an hour hit me like a sledgehammer with its final panel. Teachers are amazing. Go thank your nearest teacher.

item.title: The Trading Game: A Confession by Gary Stevenson
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

I've readlly enjoyed his Youtube channel "Gary's Economis" for a while now. In that light I was slightly disappointed that the book was mostly biographic, with not a whole lot of economics. That said, Stevensen is a REALLY great writer. Lots of very funny anecdotes, and insights. Worth the read.

item.title: Technofeudalism: What Killed Capitalism by Yanis Varoufakis
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Non-Fiction

Varoufakis is a surprisingly great writer. The first chapter draws an extremely compelling extended metaphor between physics and philosphy and economics which blew me away. His core thesis is that we have moved beyond capitalism, and far from the socialist utopia which many predicted would be the downfall of capitalism, we ended up with something weird, and worse than capitalism. Very compelling read, and one of the more influential in how I currently percieve the world economy.

item.title: Laziness does not exist: A defense of the exhausted, exploited, and overworked by Devon Price
item.description:
Rating: üü•

Type: Non-Fiction

I found this to be less interesting than I hoped. Yep, if you work too hard you will burn out, and there are physiological signs. Idk, maybe some people need a book to tell them this, but I found it obvious and tedious

item.title: For the benefit of mankind by Liu Cixin
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Fiction

Cixin Liu did that really cool thing where he managed to thread the needle between a scathing critique of capital, while also criticising a reactionary authoritarian communist attempt at redistribution

item.title: Bloom by Ruth Kassinger
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Non-Fiction

This book is GREAT. It had me absolutley obsessed with a topic I previously knew nothing about. The book is covers the bilogoy, ecology and biotechnology of algea. It somehow had me turning pages faster I could have possibly thought given the topic. By the end I was obsessed and looking at ingredients on the back of boxes to identify the algal products inside.

item.title: War & Peace & War: 20 Years In Afghanistan by Andrew North
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

I really liked this one. It is a history of the last 20 years in Afghanistan, told biographically through the eyes of the authors collegues. This method of history is deeply personal, and I think an illuminating way to personally understand WHY things happened how they did in a sociological context.

item.title: In Ascension by Martin MacInnes
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Fiction

A surprisingly humanist piece of Sci-Fi. This piece manages to both be both VERY accurate in the science, yet mostly interested in the humanity of is characters

item.title: How to Predict the Unpredictable The Art of Outsmarting Almost Everyone by William Poundstone
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

This one was really good. The central premise is that humans are really bad at true randomness, and we fall into very predicatble patterns while trying to do random. The book then outlines the mistakes we tend to make (and practical advice in how you could exploit those blindspots)

item.title: The Internet Con: How to seize the means of computation by Cory Doctorow
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Non-Fiction

Typically I am a very materialist (philosophically, not literally) person, and as a results this was one of the more impactful political books I have ever read. In many cases power is downstream from technology, and Doctorow expertly identifies the problems, their causes and their solutions. More than any other pice, this is a guidebook for the necessary changes to affect downstream changes.

item.title: Froth: The Science of Beer by Mark Dredge
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Non-Fiction

Of all the books I've read about beer (3) this remains my favourite. Probably because it was written by a physicist.

item.title: The Three-Body Problem by Liu Cixin
item.description:
Rating: ‚≠ê

Type: Fiction

I never thought I would take "Astro-socialogy" as a serious concept before reading this. Read the whole series, seriously.

item.title: Dune by Frank Herbert
item.description:
Rating: üü©

Type: Fiction

I read Dune, and Dune Messiah where it got a bit too weird. The original is where it is at. The book is at its most interesting when it is talking about real politik.
